citeinfo.origin: University of Rhode Island Environmental Data Center
citeinfo.title: 2016 Submerged Aquatic Vegetation Mapping for Rhode Island Coastal Waters; SAV16

pubinfo.publish: University of Rhode Island Environmental Data Center

citeinfo.othercit: Suggested bibliographic reference: RIGIS, 2017. Submerged Aquatic Vegetation (2012); SAV16. Rhode Island Geographic Information System (RIGIS) Data Distribution System, URL: http://www.rigis.org, Environmental Data Center, University of Rhode Island, Kingston, Rhode Island (last date accessed:30 June 2017).

descript.abstract: Aerial imagery was collected for all of Rhode Island coastal areas over two days in June (15th and 26th) during the low tides of the month. Aerial photo collection followed protocals from Finkbeiner et al. (2001). Based on these guidelines, photos were taken at a low sun angle, two hours withing low tide, when wind and atmospheric haze were minimal, and when water clarity was high. Altitude of the aircraft during photo aquisition was about 16,000ft (Quantum Spatial, 2016). Water clarity was measured by volunteers using secchi disks as target dates for acquisition of aerial photography approached. Aerial imagery was turned into an orthophotographic basemap by the photogrammetric vendor (Quantum Spatial). Photo signatures of SAV were delineated on the orthophotography and taken into the field for verification. Field verification was done using GPS and underwater video. Final delineations of SAV polygons included field verification of the deep water edge and other GPS points collected on the water.
descript.purpose: Submerged aquatic vegetation beds (SAV) are a critical estuarine habitat. In Rhode Island, the main species of SAV is eelgrass (Zostera marina). Mapping the extent and quantifying the acreage of eelgrass is a critical first step toward understanding, managing, and protecting these vital habitats. SAV has been identified as a critical marine resource and is currently protected by both Federal and state legislation. As such the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has a stated policy on the assessment, protection, and study of SAV as a recommendation for all member states.

idinfo.useconst: These data are presented as is and it is up to the user of these data to understand the accuracy and associated error included herein. Additionally, these data should NOT replace field surveys of SAV especially for permitting and compliance. Please see accompanying report for details. idinfo.datacred: Rhode Island Eelgrass Mapping Taskforce. Including: Michael Bradley, URI-EDC; Caitlin Chaffee, RI CRMC; Kenny Raposa, NBNERR. Funding for this work is from RI Coastal Resources Management Council. Collection and production of 2016 orthophotograpy was made possible thanks to the USGS Geospatial Product and Service Contract.

dataqual.logic: Tests of logical consistency were done using vendor software. All polygons were tested for internal closure with vendor software.

citeinfo.title: 2016 SAV polygons for all coastal Rhode Island waters

srcinfo.srccitea: 2016 SAV polygons for all coastal Rhode Island waters
srcinfo.srccontr: 2016 SAV polygons for all coastal Rhode Island waters.

procstep.procdesc: Polygons of SAV were heads-up digitized on the orthophotography collected during June of 2016. Historical datasets from 2012 and 2006 were also used to zero-in on potential areas of SAV. Polygons were loaded onto a GPS enabled tablet with ArcPad and taken out on a boat for field investigations. We used an underwater video camera to verify presence of eelgrass. We collected GPS points in the field and coded them as having eelgrass or not. We focused on the center of the polygon and the deepwater edge of the eelgrass beds. Final delineations of eelgrass were adjusted to include the GPS field data. Not all polygons were field visited. As such we included a field (ground-truth year) in the attribute table.
